H0.text: New stars originate from fusion in red giants, a process that occurs during the star's life cycle—which includes formation, life, and death—in the Universe.

H1.text: In molecular clouds of gas, new stars originate in the Universe as part of their life cycle, which includes formation, life, and death.

H2.text: In radiation from black holes are the origins of new stars in the Universe.

H3.text: New stars originate from large fragments of antimatter in the Universe.

A4.text: Star formation is the process by which dense regions within molecular clouds in interstellar space—sometimes referred to as 'stellar nurseries' or 'star-forming regions'—collapse and form stars.

A5.text: Population III stars formed from primordial hydrogen after the Big Bang.
